explanation: To determine whether lfs_crc is dead code you must prove whether any reachable call site can execute it (and under what conditions/timing). Therefore include the immediate callers of lfs_crc so their call sites and conditions can be inspected (lfs_bd_crc, lfs_dir_fetchmatch, lfs_dir_commitprog, lfs_dir_commitcrc). Also include the callers of those functions up the call graph so you can establish reachability from public/entry points and determine whether removal would affect program behaviour (lfs_dir_fetch, lfs_dir_find, lfs_mount_, lfs_fs_parent, lfs_dir_commitattr, lfs_dir_compact, lfs_dir_relocatingcommit). Inspecting these function bodies is required to see whether calls to lfs_crc are unconditional, conditional, dependent on configuration/state, or only affect timing/side-effects — all necessary to decide if lfs_crc truly qualifies as dead code under MISRA.
